procedure.summary: Stir the sauce on a medium heat until it starts to simmer.
procedure.description: The heat will cause some of the liquid to evaporate, which helps the sauce to thicken and has the added benefit of making the flavours more concentrated. Keeping stirring the sauce until it begins to gently simmers. If the teriyaki sauce is sticking to the bottom of the pot or vigorously boiling, turn down the heat.

procedure.summary: Test the flavour and consistency of the sauce with a spoon.
procedure.description: Dip your spoon into the sauce and note whether the sauce sticks to the spoon. If the sauce coats the spoon, this indicates that it will stick well to the ingredients in your meal. Leave the sauce on the spoon for 5 seconds before tasting it to give it a chance to cool. This will help you to be able to taste all the flavours in the sauce and will give you an accurate idea of the consistency of the sauce at a cooler temperature. If the sauce is already at your desired consistency, remove it from the heat.

procedure.summary: Leave the sauce on the heat until you are happy with the consistency.
procedure.description: The longer that you leave the sauce on the heat; the thicker it will become. When you are happy with the texture, remove the sauce from the heat and allow it to cool. If your sauce has sugar or gelatin in, it will keep thickening while it cools.

procedure.summary: Add a dash of water if the sauce is too thick.
procedure.description: Once the sauce begins to cool, you may notice that it becomes thicker. If you are unhappy with the consistency, simply stir in a little water. Start with a few drops at first and then evaluate if you need more. Continue adding water until you are happy with the texture of the sauce. The flavours will weaken slightly as you add water to the sauce.
